abstracts.cdata!:
The project is rated satisfactory, with
            a likely sustainability, and substantial institutional
            development impact. Nonetheless, lessons address issues
            regarding targeted recruitment, and quality improvement. The
            innovative recruitment scheme, was targeted to voluntary
            candidates entering the D2 (five-semester post Secondary
            Diploma Course) program, also offered to teachers from
            deprived, and remote areas, granting the opportunity to
            upgrade their skills, and access preferential treatment to
            the civil service, through a teaching post upon graduation,
            additionally enhanced by the possibility of returning to the
            rural areas. This became an equity objective, since not only
            were teachers more committed to their own communities, but
            they had the advantages of knowing the local language, and
            the acceptance of belonging to the community. However, this
            scheme proved mostly short lived, based on the recruitment
            dilemma for the highest scoring, a selection not necessarily
            from deprived areas, but on average from urban areas.
            Furthermore, education quality improvement will not be
            sustained, unless action plans maximize staff utilization,
            and support a continued development, in a collaborative
            effort by institutions, participants, and external
            contributors, with the need to model the program along a
            wide range of pedagogic approaches, redefining the role of
            head teachers in accordance to the country's changing context.
